To my lady sister Manatine Probus her brother greetings. Above all I pray to the Lord God concerning your well-being that you receive my letter in good health and in good spirits. I want you to know, my lady sister, (''that you must'') go to Petronius my guarantor. Get from him out of my pay one and a half (''talents'')...}} ==Diachronic phonetic description== ===Loss of vowel quantity distinction=== The ancient distinction between long and short vowels was lost in popular speech at the beginning of the Koine period. "By the mid-second century [BCE] however, the majority system had undergone important changes, most notably monophthongization, the loss of distinctive length, and the shift to a primary stress accent."{{Harvcoltxt|Horrocks|1997|p=109}} From the 2nd century BC, spelling errors in non-literary Egyptian papyri suggest stress accent and loss of vowel length distinction. The widespread confusion between {{lang|grc|ο}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} in Attic inscriptions starting in the 2nd century AD was probably caused by a loss of vowel length distinction.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=94}} ===Transition to stress accent=== The means of accenting words changed from [[Pitch accent|pitch]] to [[Stress (phonology)|stress]], meaning that the accented syllable had only one tone option (high) and was presumably louder and/or stronger. This shift directly corresponded with monophthongization and the loss of vowel timing distinctions, which destroyed the environment in which a pitch accent could be sustained.Horrocks (2010: 118, 169) From the mid 2nd century BC, spelling errors all over the Mediterranean, including occasional graphic omissions of unaccented vowels, suggest a loss of vowel length distinction, which is commonly thought to result in the loss of tonal accent. More evidence of stress accent appears in poetry starting from the late 2nd century AD – early 3rd century AD.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=130}} ===Diphthongs=== ====Spurious diphthongs==== Before a consonant, the diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} had started to become monophthongal in Attic as early as the 6th century BC, and pronounced like {{lang|grc|ε̄}}, probably as {{IPA|/eː/}}. From the late 4th century BC in Attic, the [[spurious diphthong]] (pseudo-diphthong) {{lang|grc|ει}} (now notating both etymological {{lang|grc|ει}} and etymological {{lang|grc|ε̄}}) came to be pronounced like {{lang|grc|ῑ}}, probably as {{IPA|/iː/}} (with the [[vowel quality|quality]] that the [[Digraph (orthography)|digraph]] still has in modern Greek).{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=69–72}}. Diphthong '{{lang|grc|ει}}' had already merged with {{lang|grc|ι}} in the 5th century BC in regions such as [[Argos]] or in the 4th century BC in [[Corinth]] (e.g. {{lang|grc|ΛΕΓΙΣ}}).{{Citation needed|date=April 2008}} It was also the case in [[Boeotia]] in the early 4th century BC (Allen, ''op. cit.'', page 74) Before a vowel, the diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} did not follow the same evolution as pre-consonantal {{lang|grc|ει}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=72–73}} One theory to explain this difference is that pre-vocalic {{lang|grc|ει}} may have kept a diphthongal value {{IPA|[ej]}} until the 4th century BC, the {{IPA|[j]}} being progressively perceived as a glide from {{IPA|/e/}} to the next vowel.This perceived glide would explain why, in the 5th and 4th centuries BC in Attic, though there was no pre-vocalic {{lang|grc|ε̄}} that {{lang|grc|ει}} may have been confused with, {{lang|grc|ει}} was often written as {{lang|grc|ε}}; indeed, while the confusion seems to have ceased after the 4th century BC, several etymological pre-vocalic {{lang|grc|ει}} remain in altered {{lang|grc|ε̆}} form in Koine Greek. Such a perceived glide may actually be even older, since in Homeric verses etymological pre-vocalic {{lang|grc|ει}} is often written either as a short {{lang|grc|ε}} or a long {{lang|grc|ει}}. Allen, ''op. cit.'', page 83–84. From the late 4th century BC, the pre-vocalic diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} came to be confused with {{lang|grc|η}}, which implies that, unlike before a consonant, it retained the value {{IPA|/eː/}}, probably with a loss of openness distinction with {{lang|grc|η}}; for later evolution, refer to {{lang|grc|η}} below. Starting from the 6th century in Attic, the diphthong {{lang|grc|ου}} had been monophthongized and confused with {{lang|grc|ο̄}}. While its initial value had probably been {{IPA|/oː/}}, it must have evolved to {{IPA|/uː/}} quite early (possibly in the 6th century BC, and at any rate before 350 BC); this vowel quality has been preserved through modern times.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=75–78}} ====Short-first-element i diphthongs==== Diphthong {{lang|grc|αι}} was probably monophthongized at first as {{IPA|/ε(ː)/}}.with a possible intermediate stage of {{IPA|/æ(ː)/}}, c.f. Horrocks (2010: 119,161) This value is attested in Boeotian in the early 4th century BC with the Boeotian spelling of {{lang|grc|η}} for {{lang|grc|αι}}.This spelling (e.g. [[Inscriptiones Graecae|IG]] 7.1672.6 {{lang|grc|Θειβῆος}} = {{lang|grc|Θηβαῖος}}, [[Corinna]] fr. 664 {{lang|grc|μέμφομη}} = {{lang|grc|μέμφομαι}}; cf. {{Harvcoltxt|Lejeune|1972|pp=230–1}}) indicates that the transition of {{lang|grc|αι}} to {{IPA|/ɛː/}} had taken place in Boeotian but not in Attic in the early 4th century BC {{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=74}}. Confusion of {{lang|grc|αι}} with {{lang|grc|ε}} suggests that this transition had taken place by the mid 2nd century BC in Egyptian Greek.Randall Buth, ''Ἡ Κοινὴ Προφορά'', page 3. Further confusion between {{lang|grc|αι}} and {{lang|grc|ε}} is found in Palestine in the early 2nd century,Buth, ''op. cit.'', page 3. and the confusion between {{lang|grc|αι}} and {{lang|grc|ε}} starting from c. 125 AD in Attic suggests that the monophthongization took place in the early 2nd century AD in learned Attic.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=79}} Allen thinks the transition to {{IPA|/e/}} (i.e. loss of openness distinction with {{lang|grc|ε}}) to have taken place later; while Allen is not very explicit on this point, this theory seems based on the observation that while both {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|αι}} are confused with {{lang|grc|ε}}, {{lang|grc|αι}} is not confused with {{lang|grc|η}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=79}} The transition would then have taken place after the transition of {{lang|grc|η}} to {{IPA|/iː/}}~{{IPA|/i/}} was over in mainstream Greek, that is to say no earlier than the late Roman period or early Byzantine period. However, not all scholars seem to agree. No reference on this point of debate has been found. Diphthong {{lang|grc|οι}} was monophthongized as {{IPA|/yː/}} or {{IPA|/y/}} (depending on when the loss of vowel length distinction took place).With possible intermediate states {{IPA|/øi/}} and {{IPA|/ø(ː)/}}, c.f. Horrocks (2010: 162.) This is attested in Boeotian in the early as the 3rd century BC with a spelling of {{lang|grc|υ}} for {{lang|grc|οι}}, but this was probably a dialectal trait.{{Harvcoltxt|Lejeune|1972|pp=230–1}}, {{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=81}}: e.g. [[Inscriptiones Graecae|IG]] 7.283 etc. {{lang|grc|τῦς ἄλλυς προξένυς}} = {{lang|grc|τοῖς ἄλλοις προξένοις}}, Still, diphthong {{lang|grc|οι}} must have kept a diphthongal value at least in learned language until Roman times, as it is transcribed as ''oe'' in Latin. Further evidence of monophthongization is found from the early 1st century BC in Egyptian Greek, as well as in the early 2nd century AD in Palestine. Monophthongization in learned language seems attested by a {{lang|grc|υ}} spelling for {{lang|grc|οι}} found in a text dated from the early 2nd century AD and another from c. 240 AD.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=81}} (Look up note on evolution of {{lang|grc|υ}} for subsequent evolution.) Koine Greek initially seems to feature diphthong {{lang|grc|υι}}, which had been progressively monophthongized to {{IPA|/yː/}} (written {{lang|grc|υ}} for {{lang|grc|ῡ}}) in Attic from the 6th century BC to the 4th century BC but retained in other Greek dialects.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=81}}, note 54 It was later monophthongized as {{IPA|/yː/}} or {{IPA|/y/}} (depending on when the loss of vowel length distinction took place). (The author of these lines has not found any reference on when this change took place, but this transition may be phonologically linked to, and at any rate is quite unlikely to have taken place after, the similar transition of {{lang|grc|οι}} to {{IPA|/y(ː/)}}). (See discussion on {{lang|grc|υ}} below for subsequent evolution.) ====Short-first-element u diphthongs==== Diphthongs {{lang|grc|αυ}} and {{lang|grc|ευ}} lost their ancient value of {{IPA|/au, eu/}} and [[fortition|fortified]] to a fricative consonantal pronunciation of {{IPA|/aβ, eβ/}} or {{IPA|/av, ev/}}, through the likely intermediate stages of {{IPA|/aw, ew/}} and then {{IPA|/aβʷ, eβʷ/}}Horrocks 2010: 169Comparable to the modern pronunciation of {{IPA|/av, ev/}} (partially [[Assimilation (linguistics)|assimilated]] to {{IPA|[af, ef]}} before [[voiceless consonant]]s {{lang|grc|θ}}, {{lang|grc|κ}}, {{lang|grc|ξ}}, {{lang|grc|π}}, {{lang|grc|ς}}, {{lang|grc|τ}}, {{lang|grc|φ}}, {{lang|grc|χ}}, and {{lang|grc|ψ}}, this assimilation being undated). Sporadic confusions of {{lang|grc|αυ/ευ}} with {{lang|grc|αβ/εβ}}, which attest a fricative pronunciation, are found as early as 3rd century BC Boeotia and in 2nd century BC Egypt.In Egypt ῥάυδους for ῥάβδους, Gignac (1976: page 233, note 1) Further such confusions appear rarely in the papyri at the beginning of the 1st century AD.{{lang|grc|πνευτύνις}} for {{lang|grc|πνεβτύνι}} for the early bilabial fricative stage, Buth, ''op. cit.'', page 4, note 8, citing Francis Thomas Gignac, ''A Grammar of the Greek Papyri of the Roman and Byzantine Periods. Volume One: Phonology. Milan 1976'', pages 68, note 1, and page 70. However, Gignac notes that before the Late Roman/Early Byzantine period spellings with {{lang|grc|α(υ)ου/ε(υ)ου}} are more common, which more likely represent the earlier transitional phases of {{IPA|/aw, ew/}} or {{IPA|/aβʷ, eβʷ/}}.e.g. fluctuation among writing {{lang|grc|φλαυου–}}, {{lang|grc|φλαου–}} or {{lang|grc|φλαυ–}} for Latin ''Flauius'', Gignac (1976: 232). Allen also believes that the fricative pronunciation was not generalized at once; for instance, Jewish catacombs inscriptions still show a diphthongal value in the 2nd–3rd century AD.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=80}}, note 47 Confusion of {{lang|grc|αυ}} and {{lang|grc|ευ}} with {{lang|grc|αβ/εβ}} becomes increasingly common in late Roman and early Byzantine times, which suggests that it had been generalized by this time. Outside of Egypt, spellings with {{lang|grc|αβ/εβ}} are also found in Asia Minor, from the Late Roman period.{{cite book|last1=Schwyzer|first1=Eduard|title=Griechische Grammatik|date=1990|publisher=Verlag C.H. Beck|location=Munich|isbn=3-406-01339-2|pages=198|edition=6th}} Finally, indirect evidence comes from transcriptions into foreign languages, such as Coptic ''Hippef'' for {{lang|grc|ἱππεῦ}} (2nd century AD),Schwyzer (1990: 198) or Byzantine Late Hebrew/Aramaic transcriptions of {{lang|grc|αυ/ευ}} with אב (''ab-'').Bubeník (1989: 228) ====Long-first-element i diphthongs==== Diphthong {{lang|grc|ῃ}}note that the subscript {{lang|grc|ι}} notation is medieval, the {{lang|grc|ι}} is adscript in ancient texts where it appears had started to become monophthongal in Attic at least as early as the 4th century BC as it was often written {{lang|grc|ει}} and probably pronounced {{IPA|[eː]}}. In Koine Greek, most {{lang|grc|ῃ}} were therefore subjected to the same evolution as original classical {{IPA|/eː/}} and came to be pronounced {{IPA|/i(ː)/}}. However, in some inflexional endings (mostly 1st declension dative singular and subjunctive 3S), the evolution was partially reverted from c. 200 BC, probably by analogy of forms of other cases/persons, to {{lang|grc|η}} and was probably pronounced {{IPA|/eː/}} at first (look up note on evolution of {{lang|grc|η}} for subsequent evolution).{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=85–86}} Other long-first-element {{lang|grc|ι}} diphthongs ({{lang|grc|ᾳ}} and {{lang|grc|ῳ}}once again, the subscript notation is medieval became monophthongal by the 2nd century BC, as they were written {{lang|grc|α}} and {{lang|grc|ω}};{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=86}}. However, when augmented from {{lang|grc|οι}} in verbs, diphthong {{lang|grc|ῳ}} had been altered to {{lang|grc|οι}} instead ({{Harvcolnb|Allen|1987|p=87}}), note 70 the former was probably pronounced {{IPA|/a(ː)/}}, while the later may have been pronounced {{IPA|/ɔ(ː)/}} at first if openness distinction had not been lost yet, and was eventually pronounced {{IPA|/o(ː)/}} at any rate (look up discussion of single vowels {{lang|grc|ο}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} below for details). From the 2nd century AD, Atticism caused for a widespread reintroduction of the ancient spelling with the final {{lang|grc|ι}}, but in any case was not pronounced.Horrocks (2010: 175) ====Long-first-element u diphthongs==== When augmented from {{lang|grc|ευ}} in verbs, diphthong {{lang|grc|ηυ}} had been altered to {{lang|grc|ευ}} from the 4th century BC.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=87}}, note 70 Other long-first-element {{lang|grc|υ}} diphthongs ({{lang|grc|ᾱυ}}, {{lang|grc|ηυ}} and {{lang|grc|ωυ}}) had become monophthongal from the 1st century BC, as they were written as {{lang|grc|α}}, {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ω}};{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=87}} the first was probably pronounced {{IPA|/a(ː)/}}, while the two later may have been pronounced {{IPA|/ɛ(ː)/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ(ː)/}} at first if openness distinction had not been lost yet ({{IPA|/e(ː)/}} and {{IPA|/o(ː)/}} otherwise), and were eventually pronounced {{IPA|/i(ː)/}} and {{IPA|/o(ː)/}} at any rate (look up discussions of single vowels {{lang|grc|ο}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} and single vowel {{lang|grc|η}} below for details). ===Single vowel quality=== Apart from {{lang|grc|η}}, simple vowels have better preserved their ancient pronunciation than diphthongs. As noted above, at the start of the Koine Greek period, pseudo-diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} before consonant had a value of {{IPA|/iː/}}, whereas pseudo-diphthong {{lang|grc|ου}} had a value of {{IPA|[uː]}}; these vowel qualities have remained unchanged through Modern Greek. Diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} before vowel had been generally monophthongized to a value of {{IPA|/i(ː)/}} and confused with {{lang|grc|η}}, thus sharing later developments of {{lang|grc|η}}. The quality of vowels {{lang|grc|α}}, {{lang|grc|ε̆}}, {{lang|grc|ι}} and {{lang|grc|ο}} have remained unchanged through Modern Greek, as {{IPA|/a/}}, {{IPA|/e/}}, {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/o/}}.Note again that in this case the symbols {{IPA|/e, o/}} transcribe true [[mid vowel]]s, rather than close-mid values. Vowels {{lang|grc|ο}} and {{lang|grc|ω}} started to be regularly confused in Attic inscriptions starting in the 2nd century AD, which may indicate that the quality distinction was lost around this time. However, this may as well indicate the loss of length distinction, with an earlier or simultaneous loss of quality distinction. Indeed, the fact that some less systematic confusion is found in Attic inscriptions from the 4th century BC may alternatively point to a loss of openness distinction in the 4th century BC, and the systematization of the confusion in the 2nd century AD would then have been caused by the loss of length distinction. The quality distinction between {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ε}} may have been lost in Attic in the late 4th century BCE, when pre-consonantic pseudo-diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} started to be confused with {{lang|grc|ι}} and pre-vocalic diphthong {{lang|grc|ει}} with {{lang|grc|η}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=73}}. This evolution had probably happened by the early 4th century BCE in Boeotian but definitively not in Attic, as shown by e.g. Boeotian {{lang|grc|πατειρ}} vs Attic {{lang|grc|πατήρ}} ({{Harvcolnb|Allen|1987|p=74}}) C. 150 AD, Attic inscriptions started confusing {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ι}}, indicating the appearance of a {{IPA|/iː/}} or {{IPA|/i/}} (depending on when the loss of vowel length distinction took place) pronunciation that is still in usage in standard Modern Greek; however, it seems that some locutors retained the {{IPA|/e̝/}} pronunciation for some time, as Attic inscriptions continued to in parallel confuse {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ε}}, and transcriptions into Gothic and, to some extent, old Armenian transcribe {{lang|grc|η}} as e.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=74–75}} Additionally, it is noted that while interchange of {{lang|grc|η}} and {{lang|grc|ι/ει}} does occur in the Ptolemaic and Roman period, these only occur in restrictive phonetic conditions or may otherwise be explained due to grammatical developments.As an example, c.f. the Ptolemaic papyrus above in which {{lang|grc|η}} shifts to {{IPA|/i/}} in pre-labial conditions. As for grammatical explanations of certain errors, the falling together of perfect and aorist tenses in the Koine could have created confusion between aorist {{lang|grc|ἧκα}} and perfect {{lang|grc|εἷκα}}, c.f. Horrocks (2010: 168) Koine Greek adopted for vowel {{lang|grc|υ}} the pronunciation {{IPA|/y/}} of Ionic-Attic. Confusion of {{lang|grc|υ}} with {{lang|grc|ι}} appears in Egyptian papyri from the 2nd century BC and 2nd century AD, suggesting a pronunciation of {{IPA|/i/}}, but this occurs only in restricted phonetic conditions or may be a regional trait (since Coptic did not have {{IPA|/y/}}.)Horrocks (2010: 168-69){{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=68}} Transcriptions into Gothic and, to some extent, Armenian suggest that {{lang|grc|υ}} still retained a {{IPA|/y/}} pronunciation, and the transition to {{IPA|/i/}} in mainstream Greek is thought to have taken place at the end of the 1st millennium.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=68}}, note 14 ===Loss of aspiration=== The aspirate breathing ([[aspiration (phonetics)|aspiration]], referring here to the phoneme {{IPA|/h/}}, which is usually marked by the [[rough breathing]] sign), which was already lost in the [[Ionic Greek|Ionic]] idioms of [[Asia Minor]] and the [[Aeolic Greek|Aeolic]] of [[Lesbos Island|Lesbos]] ([[psilosis]]),{{Harvcoltxt|Lejeune|1972|pp=281–2}} later stopped being pronounced in Koine Greek. Incorrect or hypercorrect markings of assimilatory aspiration (i.e. un-aspirated plosive becomes aspirated before initial aspiration) in Egyptian papyri suggest that this loss was already under way in Egyptian Greek in the late 1st century BC.e.g. {{lang|grc|ἐπ' οἷς}} for {{lang|grc|ἐφ' οἷς}}, Randall Buth, ''op. cit.'', page 5–6, citing Gignac, ''op. cit.'', page 137–138. Transcriptions into foreign languages and consonant changes before aspirate testify that this transition must not have been generalized before the 2nd century AD, but transcriptions into Gothic show that it was at least well under way in the 4th century AD.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=53}} ===Consonants=== Among consonants, only {{lang|grc|β}}, {{lang|grc|δ}}, {{lang|grc|γ}} and {{lang|grc|ζ}} are certain to have changed from Classical Greek. Consonants {{lang|grc|φ}}, {{lang|grc|θ}} and {{lang|grc|χ}} are assumed to have changed, too, but there is some disagreement amongst scholars over evidence for these. The consonant {{lang|grc|ζ}}, which had probably a value of {{IPA|/zd/}} in Classical Attic{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=56}}{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=58}}, note 115 (though some scholars have argued in favor of a value of {{IPA|/dz/}}, and the value probably varied according to dialects – see [[Zeta (letter)]] for further discussion), acquired the sound {{IPA|/z/}} that it still has in Modern Greek, seemingly with a geminate pronunciation {{IPA|/zz/}} at least between vowels. Attic inscriptions suggest that this pronunciation was already common by the end of the 4th century BC.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=58}} Horrocks agrees with Gignac on finding evidence that [[geminate]] consonants tended to simplify beginning from the 3rd century BC, as seen in their arbitrary use in less literate writing.e.g. {{lang|grc|πρόγραμα}} for {{lang|grc|πρόγραμμα}}, Horrocks (2010: 171, 175)Gignac (1976: 154-165) However, degemination was not carried out universally, as seen where the South Italian, south-eastern and some Asia Minor dialects preserve double consonants.Horrocks (2010: 274) Consonants {{lang|grc|φ}}, {{lang|grc|θ}}, which were initially pronounced as [[Aspirated consonant|aspirate]]s {{IPA|/pʰ/}} and {{IPA|/tʰ/}}, developed into fricatives {{IPA|/f/}}An intermediate stage of {{IPA|[ɸ]}} has been proposed by some, but there is no specific evidence to support this ({{Harvcolnb|Allen|1987|p=25}}) and {{IPA|[θ]}}.A transitional affricate stage, e.g. {{IPA|/pf, tθ, kx/}}, is also possible. This would then simplify to {{IPA|/f, θ, x/}} in the contexts of clusters involving other voiceless fricatives due to resulting difficult pronunciations, e.g. {{IPA|/s/}} or {{IPA|/f/}}, c.f. {{harvcoltxt|Horrocks|2010|p=171}}. On the other hand, there is no specific evidence of the transition of consonant {{lang|grc|χ}} from aspirate {{IPA|/kʰ/}} to fricative {{IPA|[x~ç]}} in the Koine Greek period. There is evidence for fricative {{lang|grc|θ}} in Laconian in the 5th century BC,e.g. Aristophanes {{lang|grc|Εἰρήνη}}, l. 214, {{lang|grc|σιώ}} for {{lang|grc|θεώ}} ({{Harvcolnb|Allen|1987|p=26}}) but this is unlikely to have influenced Koine Greek which is largely based on Ionic-Attic. According to Allen, the first clear evidence for fricative {{lang|grc|φ}} and {{lang|grc|θ}} in Koine Greek dates from the 1st century AD in Latin Pompeian inscriptions.Particularly meaningful is ''lasfe'' found for {{lang|grc|λάσθη}} ({{Harvcolnb|Allen|1987|p=23}}) Yet, evidence suggest an aspirate pronunciation for {{lang|grc|θ}} in Palestine in the early 2nd century,Randall Buth, ''op. cit.'', page 4 and Jewish catacomb inscriptions of the 2nd–3rd century AD suggest a pronunciation of {{IPA|/f/}} for {{lang|grc|φ}}, {{IPA|/tʰ/}} for {{lang|grc|θ}} and {{IPA|/kʰ/}} for {{lang|grc|χ}}, which would testify that the transition of {{lang|grc|θ}} to a fricative was not yet general at this time, and suggests that the transition of {{lang|grc|φ}} to a fricative may have happened before the transition of {{lang|grc|θ}} and {{lang|grc|χ}}.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=24}} There may be evidence for fricative {{lang|grc|φ}} in 2nd century AD Attic, in the form of omission of the second element in the {{lang|grc|ευ}} diphthongs (which pronounced {{IPA|[ef, ev]}}) before {{lang|grc|φ}}.e.g. {{lang|grc|Ἐφρονίς}} for {{lang|grc|Εὐφρονίς}}, Horrock (2010:171), citing Konrad Meisterhans (1900), ''Grammatik der attischen Inschriften'' [[Old Armenian|Armenian]] transcriptions transcribe {{lang|grc|χ}} as {{IPA|/kʰ/}} until the 10th century AD, so it seems that {{lang|grc|χ}} was pronounced as aspirate by at least some speakers until then.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=25}} There is disagreement as to when consonants {{lang|grc|β}}, {{lang|grc|γ}} and {{lang|grc|δ}}, which were originally pronounced {{IPA|/b/}}, {{IPA|/ɡ/}}, {{IPA|/d/}}, acquired the value of {{IPA|/v/}},An intermediate stage of {{IPA|/β/}} has been proposed by some, cf. {{Harvcoltxt|Horrocks|1997|p=112}} {{IPA|[ɣ~ʝ]}}, and {{IPA|/ð/}} that they have in Modern Greek.except when preceded by a nasal consonant (μ, ν, γ); in that case, they retain their ancient sounds (e.g. {{lang|grc|γαμβρός}} > {{lang|grc|γαμπρός}} {{IPA|[ɣamˈbros]}}, {{lang|grc|ἀνήρ, ἄνδρα}} > {{lang|grc|άντρας}} {{IPA|[ˈandras]}}, {{lang|grc|ἄγγελος}} > {{lang|grc|άγγελος}} – {{IPA|[ˈaɲɟelos]}}) There is evidence of fricative {{lang|grc|γ}} as far back as the 4th century BC, in the form of omissions before a back vowel.e.g. {{lang|grc|ὀλίος}} fοr {{lang|grc|ὀλίγος}}, Gignac (1976: note 1, page 71) In the papyri from the 2nd century BC {{lang|grc|γ}} is sometimes omitted or inserted before a front vowel, which indicates a palatal allophone {{IPA|[ʝ]}} or {{IPA|[j]}}.e.g. {{lang|grc|ἱγεροῦ}} for {{lang|grc|ἱεροῦ}}, Teodorsson (1978: 186-187) However, to Allen these do not seem to have been a standard pronunciation.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|pp=31–32}} Some scholars have argued that the replacement of old Greek {{lang|grc|ϝ}} {{IPA|/w/}} with {{lang|grc|β}} in certain late classical dialects indicates a fricative pronunciation.e.g. {{lang|grc|βοικία}}, Bubeník (1989: 188) Ancient grammarians describe the plosive nature of these letters, {{lang|grc|β}} is transcribed as ''b'', not ''v'', in Latin, and [[Cicero]] still seems to identify {{lang|grc|β}} with Latin b.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=31}} Gignac finds evidence from non-literary papyri suggesting a fricative pronunciation in some contexts (mostly intervocalic) from about the 1st century AD, in the form of the use of {{lang|grc|β}} to transcribe Latin "v" (which was [[Vulgar Latin#Neutralization of /b/ and /w/|also undergoing a fortition process from semi-vowel /w/ to fricative /β/]].)e.g. {{lang|grc|Σερβικίου}} for {{lang|grc|Σερουικίου}}, Gignac (1976: 68-69) However, Allen is again sceptical that this pronunciation was generalized yet.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=32}}, note 46 Increasingly common confusion of {{lang|grc|αυ}} and {{lang|grc|ευ}} with {{lang|grc|αβ}} and {{lang|grc|εβ}} in late Roman and early Byzantine times suggests that the fricative pronunciation of {{lang|grc|β}} was common if not general by this time.Randall Buth, ''op. cit.'', page 4, note 8, citing {{Harvcoltxt|Horrocks|1997|p=111}}e.g. {{lang|grc|προσαγορεύβομε}} for {{lang|grc|προσαγορεύομαι}}, Gignac (1976: 70) Yet, it is not before the 10th century AD that transcriptions of {{lang|grc|β}} as fricative {{lang|hy|վ}} ''v'' or {{lang|grc|γ}} as voiced velar {{lang|hy|ղ}} ''ł'' (pronounced {{IPA|[ɣ~ʁ]}}) are found in Armenian, which suggests that the transition was not general before the end of the 1st millennium; however, previous transcriptions may have been learned transcriptions.{{Harvcoltxt|Allen|1987|p=32}}, note 45 Georgian loans in the 9th-10th centuries similarly show inconsistency in transcribing {{lang|grc|β}} and {{lang|grc|γ}} as a stop or fricative; {{lang|grc|β}} is consistently rendered as ბ ''b'' rather than ვ ''v'', while {{lang|grc|γ}} may be written with an adapted symbol for fricative {{IPA|/ɣ/}} or with ჟ {{IPA|[ʒ]}} (approximating {{IPA|[ʝ]}} in palatal position), but also with stop გ ''g.''{{cite journal|last1=Macharadse|first1=Neil A.|title=Zur Lautung der griechischen Sprache der byzantinischen Zeit|journal=Jahrbuch der Österreichischen Byzantinistik|date=1980|issue=29|pages=152–154}} There is probable evidence for a peculiarly early shift of {{IPA|/d/}}>{{IPA|/ð/}} in 6th century BC Elean, seen in the writing of {{lang|grc|ζ}} for {{lang|grc|δ}}.e.g. {{lang|grc|ζέ}} for {{lang|grc|δέ}}, Horrocks (2010: 31), citing Julián Méndez Dosuna, "On ⟨Z⟩ for ⟨Δ⟩ in Greek dialecal inscriptions", ''Sprache 35'', 82-114 Gignac interprets similar spellings in the Egyptian papyri beginning in the 1st century AD as the spirant pronunciation for δ in the Koine, but before the 4th century AD these only occur before {{IPA|/i/}}.e.g. {{lang|grc|ζακοσίας}} for {{lang|grc|διακοσίας}}, Gignac (1976: 75-76) However, not all scholars agree that there is a reasonable phonetic basis for the earlier fricativization of δ before ι.Horrocks (2010: 170), citing Méndez Dosuna, Review of G.C. Horrocks (1997), ''Greek: a history of the language and its speakers,'' London, in ''Journal of Greek Linguistics'' 1, 274-95 The weakness of final {{lang|grc|ν}} {{IPA|/n/}}, frequently before a stop consonant, is attested in Egypt in both Hellenistic and Roman times, seen directly in graphic omission and [[hypercorrection|hypercorrect]] insertion, though its complete loss would not be carried through until the medieval period and excluding the South-Italian, south-eastern and Asia Minor dialects.Horrocks (2010: 171, 274) The development of voiced allophones {{IPA|[b]}}, {{IPA|[d]}}, {{IPA|[g]}} of voiceless stops {{lang|grc|π}}, {{lang|grc|τ}}, and {{lang|grc|κ}} after nasals is also evidenced in Pamphylia as early as the 4th century BC and in the Egyptian papyri (mostly Roman period) in the interchange with {{lang|grc|β}}, {{lang|grc|δ}}, and {{lang|grc|γ}} in post-nasal positions (where these letters retained there their ancient plosive values, as noted above.)e.g. Pamphylian πέδε for πέντε, Egyptian {{lang|grc|πέμβτης}} for {{lang|grc|πέμπτης}}, Bubeník (1989: 220, 239) Hence {{lang|grc|μπ}}, {{lang|grc|ντ}}, {{lang|grc|γκ}} would later be used for {{IPA|/b/}}, {{IPA|/d/}}, {{IPA|/g/}}, via assimilation to the second element.e.g. {{IPA|[ˈpente] > [ˈpende] > [ˈpedde] > [ˈpede]}}, Horrocks (2010: 111), c.f. Pamphylian evidence above. {{Infobox language |name= Koro |pronunciation= |states= India |region = [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[India]] |speakers=1,500 |date=2010 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam1=Possibly [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan]] |fam2=[[Greater Siangic languages|Greater Siangic]]? |fam3=[[Siangic languages|Siangic]] |iso3=jkr |glotto=koro1316 |glottorefname= Koro }}
'''Koro''' is a possibly [[Sino-Tibetan languages|Sino-Tibetan language]] spoken by approximately 800–1,500 people in the [[East Kameng district]] at the western end of [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[India]]. Few speakers are under 20 years old.<ref name=NG/> The people live among the [[Hruso people|Aka (Hruso)]], but their language is only distantly related, with distinct words for numerals, body parts, and other basic vocabulary.<ref name=NG>Morrison, Dan [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/10/101005-lost-language-india-science/ "'Hidden' Language Found in Remote Indian Tribe"]. ''National Geographic Daily News'', October 5, 2010, Retrieved on October 5, 2010</ref><ref name=symp>Schmid, Randolph E. [http://www.physorg.com/news205512282.html "Undocumented language found hidden in India"]. ''Associated Press''. 5 October 2010</ref> The majority of Koro speakers live in bilingual households in which one or more members speak Ako or another indigenous language rather than Koro.<ref name="Harrison">{{cite book |last=Harrison |first=K. David |title=The Last Speakers: The Quest to Save the World's Most Endangered Languages |publisher=[[National Geographic Society]] |year=2010 |isbn=978-1-4262-0461-6}}</ref> Although it has resemblances to [[Tani languages|Tani]] farther to the east, it appears to be at least a separate branch of Sino-Tibetan.<ref>{{cite news |title=In Search for 'Last Speakers', a Great Discovery |first= |last= |newspaper=[[National Public Radio]] |date=October 5, 2010 |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=130242203 |accessdate=October 6, 2010}} (Some sound files)</ref> Researchers hypothesize it may have originated from a group of people enslaved and brought to the area.<ref name=symp/>
==Identification== Recognition in the academic literature of Koro as a distinct language goes back at least to the 2009 edition of the ''Ethnologue'' (Lewis 2009), which based its findings on a language survey conducted in 2005. It notes that Koro has only 9 percent lexical similarity with Hruso Aka, and that it is "highly dissimilar to neighboring languages".<ref>Lewis, M. Paul (ed.), 2009. ''Ethnologue: Languages of the World'', Sixteenth edition. Dallas, TX: SIL International, "Hruso".[http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=hru]</ref>
In October 2010, the ''National Geographic Daily News'' published an article corroborating the findings of the ''Ethnologue'' based on research conducted in 2008 by a linguistic team of [[K. David Harrison|David Harrison]], [[Gregory Anderson (linguist)|Gregory Anderson]], and Ganesh Murmu while documenting two [[Hruso languages]] ([[Hruso language|Aka]] and [[Dhammai language|Miji]]) as part of [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]]'s "[[Enduring Voices]]" project.<ref name= NG/> It was reported to them as a dialect of Aka, but turned out to be highly divergent.
Mark Post & [[Roger Blench]] (2011)<ref>Post, Mark W. and Roger Blench (2011). "Siangic: A new language phylum in North East India", ''6th International Conference of the North East India Linguistics Society'', Tezpur University, Assam, India, Jan 31 – Feb 2.</ref> propose that Koro is related to [[Milang language|Milang]] in a branch, or perhaps independent family, they call [[Siangic languages|Siangic]].

{{distinguish|Linguistic Atlas of Chinese Dialects}} {{Infobox book | name = Language Atlas of China | author = [[Stephen Adolphe Wurm]], [[Li Rong (linguist)|Rong Li]], Theo Baumann, Mei W. Lee | publisher = Longman | pub_date = 1987, 1989 | isbn = 978-962-359-085-3 | oclc = | dewey = | congress = }} The '''''Language Atlas of China''''' ({{zh|s=中国语言地图集|p=Zhōngguó Yǔyán Dìtú Jí}}), published in two parts in 1987 and 1989, maps the distribution of both the [[varieties of Chinese]] and minority [[languages of China]]. It was a colloborative effort by the [[Australian Academy of the Humanities]] and the [[Chinese Academy of Social Sciences]], published simultaneously in the original Chinese and in English translation.<ref name="Baker">{{cite journal | first = Hugh D.R | last = Baker | title = ''Language Atlas of China'' | journal = Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies | volume = 56 | issue = 2 | year = 1993 | pages = 398–399 | doi = 10.1017/S0041977X0000598X }}</ref> [[Endymion Wilkinson]] rated this joint venture "outstanding".<ref name ="Wilkinson">{{cite book | first = Endymion | last = Wilkinson | author-link = Endymion Porter Wilkinson | title = [[Chinese History: A New Manual]] | location = Cambridge, MA | publisher = Harvard University Asia Center | series = Harvard-Yenching Institute Monograph Series | edition = Second, Revised printing March 2013 | isbn = 978-0-674-06715-8 | page = 30}}</ref>
A second edition was published in 2012.
== Classification of Chinese varieties == [[File:Map of sinitic languages full-en.svg|thumb|upright=2|Top-level groups and supergroups of Chinese varieties identified in the ''Atlas'']] The atlas organizes the [[varieties of Chinese]] in a hierarchy of groupings, following the work of [[Li Rong (linguist)|Li Rong]]:<ref name="Kurpaska"/> * supergroups (大区 ''dàqū''): [[Mandarin dialects|Mandarin]] and [[Min dialects|Min]] * groups (区 ''qū''): [[Jin dialects|Jin]], [[Wu dialects|Wu]], [[Hui dialects|Hui]], [[Xiang dialects|Xiang]], [[Gan dialects|Gan]], [[Hakka dialects|Hakka]], [[Yue dialects|Yue]], [[Pinghua]] and groups within Mandarin and Min * subgroups (片 ''piàn'') * clusters (小片 ''xiǎopiàn'') are only identified for some subgroups * local dialects (点 ''diǎn''): localities that were surveyed
== Contents == The atlas contains 36 colour maps, divided into three sections:<ref name="Kurpaska">{{cite book | first = Maria | last = Kurpaska | title = Chinese Language(s): A Look Through the Prism of "The Great Dictionary of Modern Chinese Dialects" | publisher = [[Walter de Gruyter]] | year = 2010 | isbn = 978-3-11-021914-2 | pages = 63–64 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lCgnrA7Ke3QC&pg=PA63 }}</ref> * A. General maps ** A1 Languages in China ** A2 Chinese dialects in China ** A3 National minorities in China ** A4 Minority languages in China ** A5 Language distribution (Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region) * B. Maps of Chinese dialects ** B1 Mandarin-1 (Northeastern China) ** B2 Mandarin-2 (Beijing, Tianjin, Hebei and western Shandong) ** B3 Mandarin-3 (Henan, Shandong, northern Anhui, northern Jiangsu) ** B4 Mandarin-4 (Shaanxi, Gansu, Qinghai, Ningxia) ** B5 Mandarin-5 (Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region) ** B6 Mandarin-6 (Southwestern China) ** B7 Jin group (Shanxi and adjacent areas) ** B8 Chinese dialects (southeastern China) ** B9 Wu group (Zhejiang, Shanghai, southern Jiangsu) ** B10 Chinese dialects (southern Anhui area) ** B11 Chinese dialects (Hunan and Jiangxi) ** B12 Min supergroup (Fujian, Taiwan, eastern Guangdong and Hainan Island) ** B13 Chinese dialects: Guangdong (mainland) ** B14 Chinese dialects (Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region) ** B15 Hakka group ** B16 Chinese dialects overseas: (a) insular Southeast Asia (b) other parts of the world * C. Maps of minority languages ** C1 Minority languages in northern China ** C2 Mongolian languages ** C3 Mongolian dialects ** C4 Turkic (Tujue) languages ** C5 Manchu-Tungus languages ** C6 Minority languages in southern China ** C7 Kam-Tai languages ** C8 Miao-Yao languages ** C9 Dialects of the Miao language ** C10 Tibeto-Burman stock languages ** C11 Tibetan dialects ** C12 Minority languages (Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region) ** C13 Minority languages (Yunnan province) ** C14 Minority languages on Hainan and Taiwan islands
The maps are printed on loose white sheets measuring {{cvt|15|in|cm}} by {{cvt|20.75|in|cm}}. Each map is accompanied by a blue sheet of the same size containing explanatory notes.<ref name="Baker"/>
== Second edition == Work began on revised edition in 2002.<ref name ="Wilkinson"/> The work was published in 2012 as a joint venture between the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and the [[City University of Hong Kong]]. It consists of two volumes, dealing respectively with varieties of Chinese and minority languages.<ref>{{cite web | script-title = 中国语言地图集(第2版):汉语方言卷 | title = Zhōngguó yǔyán dìtú jí (dì 2 bǎn): Hànyǔ fāngyán juǎn | trans-title = Language Atlas of China (2nd edition): Chinese dialect volume | publisher = The Commercial Press | location = Beijing | url = http://www.cp.com.cn/book/8094abe4-a.html | access-date = 10 January 2017 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | script-title = 中国语言地图集(第2版):少数民族语言卷 | title = Zhōngguó yǔyán dìtú jí (dì 2 bǎn): shǎoshù mínzú yǔyán juǎn | trans-title = Language Atlas of China (2nd edition): Minority languages volume | publisher = The Commercial Press | location = Beijing | url = http://www.cp.com.cn/book/8094abe4-b.html | access-date = 10 January 2017 }}</ref> The revision follows the same structure as the first edition, but the number of maps has increased to 79, and the explanatory text is greatly expanded. The number of minority languages covered has also increased from 81 to 130.<ref>{{cite web | script-title = 《中国语言地图集》(第2版)评介 | trans-title = ''Language Atlas of China'' (2nd edition): review | date = 2014 | surname = Xu | given = Ruiyuan 徐睿渊 | publisher = CASS | url = http://www.cssn.cn/ts/ts_sksp/201406/t20140610_1203668.shtml | access-date = 13 January 2017 }}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://hdl.handle.net/1902.1/18939 "Digital Language Atlas of China"], compiled by Lawrence W. Crissman, version 6, 5 October 2012, Australian Centre for the Asian Spatial Information and Analysis Network (ACASIAN) GIS Data Archive. The full dataset consists of eight layers in [[ESRI shapefile]] format derived from the ''Language Atlas of China''. The initial release (under [[Creative Commons license|Creative Commons]] v3.0 – Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike) contains only a draft of the first layer, representing maps A1–4 and marking language families and major Chinese dialect groups, but not individual non-Chinese languages or subgroups of Chinese dialects.

{{for|the Buck 65 album|Language Arts (album)}}
{{None}} '''Language arts''' (also known as [[English language|English]] language arts) is the study and improvement of the arts of language. Traditionally, the primary divisions in language arts are [[literature]] and language, where language in this case refers to both [[linguistics]], and specific [[language]]s.<ref>"The Road to [[Middle-earth|Middle-Earth]]", T. A. Shippey</ref> Language arts instruction typically consists of a combination of [[Reading (process)|reading]], [[writing]] (composition), [[speaking]], and listening.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.education.com/reference/article/components-language-arts-curriculum/|title=The Four Components of the Language Arts Curriculum {{!}} Education.com|website=www.education.com|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> In schools, language arts is taught alongside [[science]], [[mathematics]], and [[social studies]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://teach.com/what/teachers-know/english-and-language-arts/|title=English and Language Arts Teacher|access-date=2017-12-24|language=en}}</ref>
==Reading== [[Reading (process)|Reading]], by definition, is the ability and knowledge of a language that allows comprehension by grasping the meaning of written or printed characters, words, or sentences. Reading involves a wide variety of print and non-print texts that helps a reader gain an understanding of the material that is being read. Reading of texts that are often included in educational curriculum include [[fiction]], [[nonfiction]], classic, and also contemporary works. Reading goes beyond calling words to understanding the information presented in a written or a visual context.
==Composition== Composition is defined as the combination of distinct parts or elements to form a whole and the manner in which these elements are combined or related.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=composition|url=https://www.thefreedictionary.com/composition|journal=The Free Dictionary}}</ref> The following are examples of composing in language arts: * The art or act of composing a [[literary]] work (i.e. novels, speeches, poems) * A short [[essay]], especially one written as an academic exercise. An essay is a short literary composition on a particular [[Theme (literature)|theme]] or subject, usually in [[prose]] and generally analytic, speculative, or interpretative. There are many types of short essays, including: **[[Five-paragraph essay]] **Argumentative essay **Cause and effect essay **Comparative essay
Compositions may also include: * [[Narrative]] essays * [[Expository]] essays * [[Persuasive]] essays * [[Technical writing]] essays * [[Research]] essays * [[Book|Books]] * [[Vignette (literature)|Vignettes]] * [[Poetry|Poems]]
== Speaking == Oration and live delivery are often key components of language arts programs. This can include through dramatic interpretation, speeches, oral interpretation of poetry, and the like. Speaking is a valuable way to enhance concepts of persuasion, and develop linguistic skills.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://englishlive.ef.com/blog/study-tips/five-reasons-speaking-english-great-way-learn/|title=Five reasons why speaking English is a great way to learn it|website=englishlive.ef.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref>
== Listening == Listening can be considered the basis for development of speaking, reading, and writing skills.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.education.com/reference/article/language-arts/|title=The Language Arts {{!}} Education.com|website=www.education.com|access-date=2017-12-24}}</ref> It is the act of understanding spoken language, and is often paired with speaking.
==See also==
* [[Rhetoric]] * [[The three Rs]] * [[Trivium (education)]]

{{refimprove|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox language family |name=Oïl |region=Northern and central [[France]], southern [[Belgium]], [[Switzerland]] |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Latino-Faliscan languages|Latino-Faliscan]] |fam4=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam5=[[Western Romance|Western]] |fam6=[[Gallo-Romance languages|Gallo-Romance]] |ancestor=[[Old French]] |child1=see below |glotto=oila1234 |glottorefname=Oil |map=Lenguas de Oil.png |mapcaption=The geographical spread of the Oïl languages (other than French) can be seen in shades of green and yellow on this map }}
The '''langues d'oïl''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|d|ɔɪ|(|l|)|,_|d|ɔː|ˈ|iː|l}}<ref>[https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/langue%20d'oil Merriam-Webster Dictionary]</ref><ref>[https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/langue_d%27oil Oxford Dictionaries]</ref><ref>[https://www.ahdictionary.com/word/search.html?q=langue+d%27oil American Heritage Dictionary]</ref> {{IPA-fr|lɑ̃ɡdɔjl|lang}})<ref>''Le [[Petit Robert]] 1'', 1990</ref> or '''oïl languages''' ({{lang-fr|langues d'oui|links=no}} {{IPA-fr|lɑ̃ɡdwi|}}) are a [[dialect continuum]] that includes standard [[French language|French]] and its closest [[Indigenous language|autochthonous]] relatives historically spoken in the northern half of [[France]], southern [[Belgium]], and the [[Channel Islands]]. These belong to the larger [[Gallo-Romance languages]], which also include the historical languages of east-central France and western [[Switzerland]] ([[Arpitania]]), southern France ([[Occitania]]), portions of northern [[Italy]], and the [[Val d'Aran]] in [[Spain]].
Linguists divide the [[Romance languages]] of France, and especially of [[Medieval France]], into three geographical subgroups: the first two are ''Langues d'oïl'' and ''[[occitan language|occitan]]'', both named after their words for 'yes' (''oïl'' and ''òc'', respectively), and the third is [[Franco-Provençal language|Franco-Provençal]] (Arpitan).
==Meanings and disambiguation== {{Refimprove|date=February 2011}} ''Langue d'oïl'' (in the singular), ''Oïl dialects'' and ''Oïl languages'' (in the plural) designate the ancient northern Gallo-Romance languages as well as their modern-day descendants. They share many linguistic features, a prominent one being the word ''oïl'' for ''yes''. (''Oc'' was and still is the southern word for ''yes'', hence the ''langue d'oc'' or ''[[Occitan language]]s''). The most widely spoken modern Oïl language is [[French language|French]] (''oïl'' was pronounced {{IPA|[o.il]}} or {{IPA|[o.i]}}, which has become {{IPA-fr|wi|}}, in modern French ''oui'').{{fact|date=May 2017}}
There are three uses of the term ''oïl'': #Langue d'oïl #Oïl dialects #Oïl languages
===Langue d'oïl=== In the singular, Langue d'oïl refers to the mutually intelligible linguistic variants of ''lingua romana'' spoken since the 9th century in northern France and southern Belgium ([[Wallonia]]), since the 10th century in the Channel Islands, and between the 11th and 14th centuries in [[England]] (the [[Anglo-Norman language]]). ''Langue d'oïl'', the term itself, has been used in the singular since the 12th century to denote this ancient linguistic grouping as a whole. With these qualifiers, ''langue d'oïl'' sometimes is used to mean the same as [[Old French]] (see ''History'' below).{{fact|date=May 2017}}
===Oïl dialects=== In the plural, ''Oïl dialects'' refer to the [[Variety (linguistics)|varieties]] of the ancient ''langue d'oïl''.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
===Oïl languages=== In the plural, ''Oïl languages'' refer to those modern-day descendants that evolved separately from the varieties of the ancient ''langue d'oïl''. Consequently, ''langues d'oïl'' today may apply either: to all the modern-day languages of this family ''except'' the French language; or to this family ''including'' French. "''Oïl'' dialects" or "French dialects" are also used to refer to the ''Oïl languages except French''—as some extant Oïl languages are very close to modern French. Because the term ''dialect'' is sometimes considered pejorative, the trend today among French linguists is to refer to these languages as ''langues d'oïl'' rather than ''dialects''.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
==Varieties== Five zones of Oïl dialects have been proposed:<ref>''Manuel pratique de philologie romane'', Pierre Bec, 1970–1971</ref>
===Frankish zone (''zone francique'')=== *[[Picard language|Picard]] *[[Walloon language|Walloon]] *[[Lorrain language|Lorrain]] *Northern [[Norman language|Norman]] (spoken north of the [[Joret line]]): including [[Anglo-Norman language|Anglo-Norman]]; [[Dgèrnésiais]] (spoken in [[Guernsey]]), [[Jèrriais]] (spoken in Jersey), [[Auregnais]] (spoken in Alderney), [[Sercquiais]] (spoken in Sark) *[[Champenois language|Eastern Champenois]]
===[[Francien language|Francien]] zone (''zone francienne'')=== *[[French language|Standard French]] Non-standard varieties: *[[Orleanais language|Orléanais]] *[[:fr:Français régional de Touraine|Tourangeau]] *[[Berrichon]] *[[Bourbonnais dialects|Bourbonnais]] *[[Champenois language|Western Champenois]] (or Eastern Francien)
===[[Burgundy (region)|Burgundian]] zone (''zone burgonde'')=== *[[Burgundian language (Oïl)|Bourguignon]] *[[Frainc-Comtou language|Franc-Comtois]]
===[[Armorica]]n zone (''zone armoricaine'')=== *Eastern Armorican: [[Angevin language|Angevin]]; [[Mayennais language|Mayennais]]; [[Manceau language|Manceau]] ([[Sarthois dialect|Sarthois]] and [[Percheron dialect|Percheron]]); Southern [[Norman language|Norman]] (spoken south of the [[Joret line]]) *Western Armorican: [[Gallo language|Gallo]] Gallo has a stronger Celtic substrate from [[Breton language|Breton]]. Gallo originated from the oïl speech of people from eastern and northern regions: [[Anjou]]; [[Maine (province)|Maine]] ([[Mayenne]] and [[Sarthe]]); and [[Normandy]]; who were in contact with Breton speakers in [[Upper Brittany]]. See [[Marches of Neustria]]
===Poitevin-Saintongeais zone (''zone poitevine'' and ''zone saintongeaise'')=== Named after the former provinces of [[Poitou]] and [[Saintonge]] *[[Poitevin language|Poitevin]] *[[Saintongeais]]
===Development=== ''For the history of phonology, orthography, syntax and morphology, see ''[[History of the French language]]'' and the relevant individual Oïl language articles.''
Each of the Oïl languages has developed in its own way from the common ancestor, and division of the development into periods varies according to the individual histories. Modern linguistics uses the following terms: *9th–13th centuries **[[Old French]] **[[Old Norman]] **etc *French **[[Middle French]] for the period 14th–15th centuries **16th century: ''français [[renaissance]]'' (Renaissance French) **17th to 18th century: ''français classique'' ([[Classical French]])
==History== ===Romana lingua=== In the 9th century, ''romana lingua'' (the term used in the ''[[Oaths of Strasbourg]]'' of 842) was the first of the Romance languages to be recognized by its speakers as a distinct language, probably because it was the most different from [[Latin]] compared with the other Romance languages (see ''[[History of the French language]]'').{{fact|date=May 2017}}
Many of the developments that we now consider typical of [[Walloon language|Walloon]] appeared between the 8th and 12th centuries. Walloon "had a clearly defined identity from the beginning of the thirteenth century". In any case, linguistic texts from the time do not mention the language, even though they mention others in the Oïl family, such as Picard and Lorrain. During the 15th century, scribes in the region called the language "Roman" when they needed to distinguish it. It is not until the beginning of the 16th century that we find the first occurrence of the word "Walloon" in the same linguistic sense that we use it today.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
===Langue d'oïl=== By late- or post-Roman times [[Vulgar Latin]] within France had developed two distinctive terms for signifying assent (''yes''): ''hoc ille'' ("this (is) it") and ''hoc'' ("this"), which became ''oïl'' and ''oc'', respectively. Subsequent development changed "oïl" into "oui", as in modern French. The term ''langue d'oïl'' itself was first used in the 12th century, referring to the Old French linguistic grouping noted above. In the 14th century, the Italian poet [[Dante Alighieri|Dante]] mentioned the ''yes'' distinctions in his ''[[De vulgari eloquentia]]''. He wrote in [[Medieval Latin]]: "''nam alii oc, alii si, alii vero dicunt oil''" ("some say 'oc', others say 'si', others say 'oïl'")—thereby distinguishing at least three classes of Romance languages: ''oc languages'' (in southern France); ''si languages'' (in [[Italy]] and [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]]) and ''oïl languages'' (in northern France).{{fact|date=May 2017}}
Other Romance languages derive their word for "yes" from the classical Latin ''sic,'' "thus", such as the [[Italian language|Italian]] ''sì'', [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Catalan language|Catalan]] ''sí'', [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] ''sim'', and even [[French language|French]] ''si'' (used when contradicting another's negative assertion). [[Sardinian language|Sardinian]] is an exception in that its word for "yes", ''eja'', is from neither origin.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Similarly [[Romanian language|Romanian]] uses ''da'' for "yes", which is of Slavic origin.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dexonline.ro/definitie/da/855336 |title=DA - DEX online |language=Romanian |accessdate=2014-08-11}}</ref>
However, neither ''lingua romana'' nor ''langue d'oïl'' referred, at their respective time, to a single homogeneous language but to [[Mutually intelligible languages|mutually intelligible linguistic varieties]]. In those times, spoken languages in Western Europe were not codified (except Latin and Medieval Latin), the region's population was considerably lower than today, and population centers were more isolated from each other. As a result, mutually intelligible linguistic varieties were referred to as one language.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
===French (Old French/Standardized Oïl) or lingua Gallicana=== In the 13th century these varieties were recognized and referred to as ''dialects'' ("idioms") of a single language, the ''langue d'oïl''. However, since the previous centuries a common literary and juridical "interdialectary" langue d'oïl had emerged, a kind of [[Koiné language|koiné]]. In the late 13th century this common langue d'oïl was named ''French'' (''françois'' in French, ''lingua gallica'' or ''gallicana'' in Medieval Latin). Both aspects of ''"dialects of a same language"'' and ''"French as the common langue d'oïl"'' appear in a text of [[Roger Bacon]], ''[[Opus Majus|Opus maius]]'', who wrote in Medieval Latin but translated thus: "''Indeed, idioms of a same language vary amongst people, as it occurs in the French language which varies in an idiomatic manner amongst the French, [[Picardy|Picards]], [[Normans]] and [[Burgundians]]. And terms right to the Picards horrify the Burgundians as much as their closer neighbours the French"''.{{fact|date=May 2017}}
It is from this period though that definitions of individual Oïl languages are first found. The Picard language is first referred to by name as ''"langage pikart"'' in 1283 in the ''[[Livre Roisin]]''. The author of the ''Vie du bienheureux Thomas Hélye de Biville'' refers to the Norman character of his writing. The ''Sermons poitevins'' of around 1250 show the Poitevin language developing as it straddled the line between oïl and oc.
As a result, in modern times the term ''langue d'oïl'' also refers to that [[Old French]] which was not as yet named ''French'' but was already—before the late 13th century—used as a literary and juridical ''interdialectary language''.
The term ''[[Francien]]'' is a linguistic [[neologism]] coined in the 19th century to name the hypothetical variant of Old French allegedly spoken by the ''late 14th century'' in the ancient province of ''Pays de France''—the then [[Paris]] region later called ''[[Île-de-France]]''. This ''Francien'', it is claimed, became the Medieval French language. Current linguistic thinking mostly discounts the ''Francien'' theory, although it is still often quoted in popular textbooks. The term ''francien'' was never used by those people supposed to have spoken the variant; but today the term could be used to designate that specific ''10th-and-11th centuries'' variant of langue d'oïl spoken in the Paris region; both variants contributed to the koine, as both were called ''French'' at that time.
===Rise of French (Standardized Oïl) versus other Oïl languages=== For political reasons it was in Paris and Île-de-France that this koiné developed from a written language into a spoken language. Already in the 12th century [[Conon de Béthune]] reported about the French court who blamed him for using words of [[Artois]].
By the late 13th century the written koiné had begun to turn into a [[standard language|spoken and written standard language]], and was named ''French''. Since then French started to be imposed on the other Oïl dialects as well as on the territories of ''langue d'oc''.
However, the Oïl dialects and ''langue d'oc'' continued contributing to the lexis of French.
In the 16th century the French language was imposed even more by the [[Ordinance of Villers-Cotterêts]] to replace Latin in judgements and official acts and deeds (although the local Oïl languages had always been the language respectively spoken in justice courts). It is argued that the Ordinance of Villers-Cotterêts was not intended to make French a national language, merely a chancery language for law and administration. Although there were competing literary standards among the Oïl languages in the mediaeval period, the centralisation of the [[Kingdom of France|French kingdom]] and its influence even outside its formal borders sent most of the Oïl languages into comparative obscurity for several centuries. The development of [[literature]] in this new language encouraged writers to use French rather than their own [[regional language]]s. This led to the decline of [[vernacular literature]].
It was the [[French Revolution]] which imposed French on the people as the official language in all the territory. As the influence of French (and in the Channel Islands, English) spread among sectors of provincial populations, cultural movements arose to study and standardise the vernacular languages. From the 18th century and into the 20th century, societies were founded (such as the "Société liégoise de Littérature wallonne" in 1856), dictionaries (such as [[George Métivier]]'s ''Dictionnaire franco-normand'' of 1870) were published, groups were formed and literary movements developed to support and promote the Oïl languages faced with competition. Until the [[World War I|First World War]], the regional [[languages of France]] were still the languages most used in the home and in the fields.{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} This was also generally the case in areas where Oïl languages were spoken. French is now the best-known of the Oïl languages.
==Literature== [[File:Bram Bilo 1890.jpg|thumb|left|The Oïl languages have literary traditions, as for example seen in this 19th-century collection of Jèrriais short stories]]
Besides the influence of [[French literature]], small-scale literature has survived in the other Oïl languages. Theatrical writing is most notable in [[Picard language|Picard]] (which maintains a genre of vernacular [[marionette]] theatre), [[Poitevin (language)|Poitevin]] and [[Saintongeais]]. Oral performance (story-telling) is a feature of [[Gallo language|Gallo]], for example, while [[Norman language|Norman]] and [[Walloon language|Walloon]] literature, especially from the early 19th century tend to focus on written texts and poetry (see, for example, ''[[Wace]]'' and ''[[Jèrriais literature]]'').
As the vernacular Oïl languages were displaced from towns, they have generally survived to a greater extent in rural areas - hence a preponderance of literature relating to rural and peasant themes. The particular circumstances of the self-governing Channel Islands developed a lively strain of political comment, and the early industrialisation in Picardy led to survival of Picard in the mines and workshops of the regions. The mining poets of Picardy may be compared with the tradition of rhyming [[Weaver Poets]] of [[Ulster Scots dialects|Ulster Scots]] in a comparable industrial milieu.
There are some regional magazines, such as ''Ch'lanchron'' (Picard), ''Le Viquet'' (Norman), ''Les Nouvelles Chroniques du Don Balleine'' [http://www.societe-jersiaise.org/langsec/chroniques.html] (Jèrriais), and ''El Bourdon'' (Walloon), which are published either wholly in the respective Oïl language or bilingually with French. These provide a platform for literary writing.
==Status== [[File:Fosses-la-Ville JPG06W.jpg|thumb|Bilingual street sign for ''market square'' in French and [[Walloon language|Walloon]]]] Apart from French, an official language in many countries (see [[List of countries where French is an official language|list]]), the Oïl languages have enjoyed little status in recent times.
Currently Walloon, [[Lorrain language|Lorrain]] (under the local name of ''Gaumais''), and [[Champenois]] have the status of regional languages of [[Wallonia]].
The Norman languages of the Channel Islands enjoy a certain status under the governments of their [[Bailiwick]]s and within the regional and lesser-used language framework of the [[British-Irish Council]]. The [[Anglo-Norman language]], a variant of Norman once the official language of England, today holds mostly a place of ceremonial honor in the United Kingdom (now referred to as ''[[Law French]]'').
The French government recognises the Oïl languages as [[languages of France]], but the [[Constitutional Council of France]] barred ratification of the [[European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages]].<ref>[http://www.conseil-constitutionnel.fr/conseil-constitutionnel/root/bank_mm/anglais/a99412dc.pdf Constitutional Council Decision 99-412 DC, European Charter for regional or minority languages]</ref>
==Influence== {{Further|Anglo-Norman language}}The ''langues d'oïl'' were more or less influenced by the native languages of the conquering [[Germanic tribes]], notably the [[Franks]]. This was apparent not so much in the vocabulary (which remained overwhelmingly of Latin origin) as in the phonology and syntax; the invading Franks, Burgundians and Normans became the rulers and their accents were imposed as standard on the rest of the population. This accounts in large part for the relative distinctiveness of French compared to other Romance languages.[[File:Bilingual signage-Gallo.jpg|thumb|Signage in [[Gallo language|Gallo]] in the metro of [[Rennes]]]] The [[English language]] was heavily influenced by contact with Norman following the [[Norman Conquest]] and much of the adopted vocabulary shows typically Norman features.
Portuguese was heavily influenced by more than a millennium of perennial contact with several dialects of both Oïl and [[Occitan language|Occitan]] language groups, in lexicon (up to 15–20% in some estimates, at least 5000 word roots), phonology and orthography.<ref>{{pt icon}} [http://oglobo.globo.com/boa-viagem/exposicao-no-museu-da-lingua-portuguesa-mostra-influencia-do-frances-na-nossa-lingua-3125512 Exhibition at the Museum of the Portuguese Language shows the French influence in our language]</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://ressources-cla.univ-fcomte.fr/gerflint/Bresil_special2/couto.pdf Contacts between French and Portuguese or the first's influences on the second] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731140340/http://ressources-cla.univ-fcomte.fr/gerflint/Bresil_special2/couto.pdf |date=2013-07-31 }}</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://www.filologia.org.br/revista/40/A%20INFLU%C3%8ANCIA%20DOS%20ESTRANGEIRISMOS.pdf The influence of loanwords in the Portuguese language: a process of globalization, ideology and communication]</ref> The influence of Occitan was, nevertheless, the most marked, through the status Provençal in particular achieved in southwestern Europe around the [[troubadour]] apex in the Middle Ages, when [[Galician-Portuguese lyric]] was developed. Aside the direct influence of Provençal literature, the presence of languages from modern-day France in the Galician-Portuguese area was also strong due to the rule of the [[Portuguese House of Burgundy|House of Burgundy]], the establishment of the Orders of [[Cluniac Reforms|Cluny]] and [[Cistercians|Cister]], the many [[Camino de Santiago (route descriptions)|sections]] of the [[Camino de Santiago|Way of St. James]] pilgrimage route that come from elsewhere in Europe out of the Iberian Peninsula, and the settlement in Iberia of people from the other side of the Pyrenees, arriving during and after the [[Reconquista]].<ref>[https://books.google.com.br/books?id=R51e_6ZUaooC&pg=PA171&lpg=PA171&source=bl&ots=hwk5MJV3jv&sig=ZjcXoHZ0r61Vi3a5LMEAT06igqc&hl=pt-BR&sa=X&ei=KTmIVfXTCveAsQSruK24DQ&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q&f=false A língua que falamos: Português, história, variação e discurso] Luiz Antônio da Silva, 2005.</ref><ref>[http://www.altotejo.org/acafa/docsn5/o_occitejano.pdf Occitejano: Sobre a origem occitana do subdialeto do Alto Tejo português] Paulo Feytor Pinto, 2012.</ref>
The [[Lusophobia|anti-Portuguese factor]] of [[Brazilian nationalism]] in the 19th century led to an increased use of the French language in detriment of Portuguese, as France was seen at the time as a model of civilization and progress.<ref>{{cite book |last= Barbosa|first= Rosana|authorlink= |title= Immigration and Xenophobia: Portuguese Immigrants in Early 19th Century Rio de Janeiro|url= |accessdate= |year= 2009|publisher= University Press of America|location= United States|isbn= 978-0-7618-4147-0|page= |pages=}}, p. 19</ref> The learning of French has historically been important and strong among the Lusophone elites, and for a great span of time it was also the foreign language of choice among the middle class of both Portugal and Brazil, only surpassed in the [[globalization|globalised]] [[postmodernity]] by English, in both, and more recently by [[Spanish language|Spanish]], in the latter.<ref>{{pt icon}} [http://www.gel.org.br/estudoslinguisticos/volumes/37/EL_V37N2_01.pdf The importance of the French language in Brazil: marks and milestones in the early periods of teaching]</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://w3.ufsm.br/revistaletras/artigos_r39/artigo39_001.pdf Presence of the French language and literature in Brazil – for a history of Franco-Brazilian bonds of cultural affection] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921053420/http://w3.ufsm.br/revistaletras/artigos_r39/artigo39_001.pdf |date=2013-09-21 }}</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://revistaescola.abril.com.br/historia/fundamentos/quais-influencias-pensamento-frances-ainda-podem-ser-vistas-brasil-471230.shtml What are the French thinking influences still present in Brazil?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150517045650/http://revistaescola.abril.com.br/historia/fundamentos/quais-influencias-pensamento-frances-ainda-podem-ser-vistas-brasil-471230.shtml |date=2015-05-17 }}</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://www.cedep.ifch.ufrgs.br/oanodafrancanobrasilaimportanciadadiplomaciacultural.pdf France in Brazil Year – the importance of cultural diplomacy]</ref>
The [[Belgian French|French spoken in Belgium]] shows some influence from [[Walloon language|Walloon]].
The development of French in [[North America]] was influenced by the speech of settlers originating from northwestern France, many of whom introduced features of their Oïl varieties into the French they spoke. (See also ''[[French language in the United States]], [[French language in Canada]]'')
==Languages and dialects with significant Oïl influence== *all [[regional languages]] spoken [[languages of France|in France]], [[languages of Belgium|Belgium]], and [[languages of Luxembourg|Luxembourg]] *[[Limburgish]], particularly [[Maastrichtian dialect|Maastrichtian]] *all [[French-based creole languages]] *[[English language|English]] (Oïl influences on vocabulary, transmitted via the [[Anglo-Norman language]] spoken by the [[upper class]]es in England in the centuries following the [[Norman conquest of England|Norman Conquest]], and later from French) *[[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] (Oïl and Occitan influences on lexicon, phonology—especially [[European Portuguese|European]], [[Macanese Portuguese|Macanese]] and Europeanized [[Brazilian Portuguese|Brazilian]] and [[Portuguese language in Africa|African]] dialects—, and orthography)

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Sociology}}{{Discrimination sidebar}}{{about||the commonly confused term|Second-class citizen}}{{Rights|By claimant}}'''Less-than-whole citizens''', sometimes referred to as "'''fragmented citizens'''"{{Cite book|title=Fragmented Citizens: The Changing Landscape of Gay and Lesbian Lives|last=Engel|first=Stephen|publisher=NYU Press|year=2016|isbn=1479809128|location=|pages=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.nyjournalofbooks.com/book-review/fragmented-citizens|title=a book review by Jane Haile: Fragmented Citizens: The Changing Landscape of Gay and Lesbian Lives|website=www.nyjournalofbooks.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-11}} refers to the social and [[Citizenship|legal status of citizens]] of a [[Sovereign state|sovereign country]] that face discrimination on a level above [[second-class citizen]]ship and below [[Citizenship|full and equal citizenship]]. While second-class citiznery restricts the freedom of language, religion, education, and [[Property|property ownership]], "less-than-whole citizens" are limited in that they have restricted [[Civil service|civil]] or military service opportunities, limitations on [[Freedom of movement|freedom of movement and association]], marriage, [[Gender Identity|gender identity, and expression]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-4798-0912-7|title=Nonfiction Book Review: Fragmented Citizens: The Changing Landscape of Gay and Lesbian Lives by Stephen M. Engel|work=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2017-05-12|language=en}} The term was developed by political scientist [[Stephen M. Engel|Stephen Engel]] in an effort to explain the [[Social change|partiality of political change]], he described it as membership in a social/racial/ethnic group "not having [[Civil and political rights|full legal protections]] against workplace, housing, family, and other kinds of discrimination." Less-than-whole citizenship, as a term, can be used to distinguish [[Nationality#Nationality versus citizenship|nationality from citizenship]] and also to establish restrictions on rights of [[Jus sanguinis|inheritance of nationality]] of children from parents (as was the case of [[Italian nationality law#Legislative History of Italian Citizenship|Italy for mothers]]). The term is in contrast to Cornell Law professor [[Michael C. Dorf|Michael Dorf]]'s designation of these types of citizenships as also "second class" in his text, however, he also uses the [[Obergefell v. Hodges|2015 ''Obergefell v. Hodges'' Supreme Court case]] and the civil rights of the [[LGBT community|LGBTQ community]] to illustrate a compartmentalization of citizenry.{{Cite journal|last=Dorf|first=Michael C.|date=January 1, 2011|title=SAME-SEX MARRIAGE, SECOND-CLASS CITIZENSHIP, AND LAW'S SOCIAL MEANINGS|jstor=41261549|journal=Virginia Law Review|volume=97|issue=6|pages=1267–1346}} == Examples == * The legal status of gay and lesbians in the United States, [[American Samoa]], [[Guam]], [[Northern Mariana Islands]], [[Puerto Rico]], the [[United States Virgin Islands|U.S. Virgin Islands]]. Since June 26, 2003, sexual activity between consenting adults of the same sex as well as same-sex [[Romeo and Juliet laws|adolescents of a close age]] has been legal nationwide, pursuant to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] ruling in ''[[Lawrence v. Texas]]''. As of June 26, 2015, all states license and recognize [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|marriage between same-sex couples]] on account of the Supreme Court decision in ''[[Obergefell v. Hodges]]''. However, the United States has no federal law outlawing discrimination nationwide, leaving residents in some states without protection from discrimination, other than from federal executive orders which have a more limited scope than from protections through federal legislation. There is no federal statute addressing employment discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. Protections at the national level are limited. Some regulations protect government employees but do not extend their protections to the private sector. Twenty-two states, the [[Washington, DC|District of Columbia]], [[Puerto Rico]], and over 140 cities and counties have enacted bans on discrimination based on sexual orientation and/or sexual identity.{{cite journal|title=Pride and Prejudice: Employment Discrimination against Openly Gay Men in the United States|journal=American Journal of Sociology|volume=117|issue=2|pages=586–626|jstor=10.1086/661653|author=András Tilcsik}} * The treatment of [[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|third-generation Aboriginal peoples in Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/pr/pub/wf/trmrslt_e.asp?term=12 |title=Words First An Evolving Terminology Relating to Aboriginal Peoples in Canada |year=2004 |publisher=Communications Branch of Indian and Northern Affairs Canada |archive-url=https://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/webarchives/20071114225541/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/pr/pub/wf/trmrslt_e.asp?term=12 |archive-date=November 14, Metis|year=2009|publisher=Aboriginal Infant Development Programs of BC|format=PDF|accessdate=June 26, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714021655/http://www.aidp.bc.ca/terminology_of_native_aboriginal_metis.pdf|archivedate=July 14, 2010|deadurl=yes|df=mdy}}{{cite late 18th century, European Canadians (and the Canadian government) encouraged assimilation of Aboriginal culture into what was referred to as "[[Culture of Canada|Canadian culture]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ch/rcap/sg/sgm6_e.html|title=Indian and Northern Affairs Canada|date=February 8, 2006|publisher=Government of Canada Web Archive-websites archived by Library and Archives Canada.|archive-url=https://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/webarchives/20071124124236/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ch/rcap/sg/sgm6_e.html|archive-date=November 24, 2007|dead-url=yes|work=Stage Three: Displacement and Assimilation|accessdate=October 3, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ch/rcap/sg/sgmm_e.html|title=Report-Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples-Indian and Northern Affairs Canada|date=February 8, 2006|publisher=Government of Canada Web Archive-websites archived by Library and Archives Canada [[Indian and Northern Affairs Canada]]|archive-url=https://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/webarchives/20071115053257/http://www.ainc-inac.gc.ca/ch/rcap/sg/sgmm_e.html|archive-date=November 15, 2007|dead-url=yes|work=Volume 1, Part 1, Chapter 6 of the ''Report of the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Peoples''|accessdate=October 3, 2009|df=mdy-all}} These attempts reached a climax in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, with a series of initiatives that aimed at complete integration of the Aboriginal peoples. These policies, which were made possible by legislation such as the [[Gradual Civilization Act]]{{cite web|url=http://caid.ca/GraCivAct1857.pdf|title=Gradual Civilization Act, 1857|publisher=Government of Canada|accessdate=October 17, 2015}} and the [[Indian Act]],{{cite web|url=http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/i-5/|title=Indian Act|publisher=Government of Canada|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130216033916/http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/I-5/|archivedate=February 16, 2013|df=mdy}} focused on European ideals of Christianity, sedentary living, agriculture, and education. * Status of women in [[Patriarchy|patriarchies]],{{Cite book|title=Societies, Networks, and Transitions: Volume 1|last=Lockard|first=Craig|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2007|isbn=9780547047669|location=|pages=111–114|quote="Today, as in the past, men generally hold political, economic, and religious power in most societies."}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cjdbRF8PXhUC&pg=PA5|title=The police power: patriarchy and the foundations of American government|publisher=Columbia University Press|year=2005|isbn=978-0-231-13207-7|pages=5–7|author=Dubber, Markus Dirk}}{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Sex and Gender|last=Malti-Douglas|first=Fedwa|publisher=Macmillan|year=2007|isbn=0-02-865960-0|location=Detroit}} and the status of men in [[Matriarchy|matriarchies]].Compare, in ''Oxford English Dictionary'' (online), entry patriarchy to entry ''matriarchy'', both as accessed November 3, 2013.{{Subscription or libraries|sentence}}{{harvp|Eller|1995|loc=pp. 161–162 & 184 & n. 84}} (p. 184 n. 84 probably Charlene, ''Introduction'')).{{harvp|Goettner-Abendroth|2009a|pp=1–2}} * Some countries, although recognising [[dual-citizenship]], may limit citizens with foreign citizenship or foreign residency to stand for public office or join the military. * Some countries bar [[naturalized citizen]]s from holding certain public offices such as [[President of the United States]]. *Situations in which a man '''Malwida von Meysenbug''' (28 October 1816 — 23 April 1903) was a German writer, her work including ''Memories of an Idealist'', the first volume of which she published anonymously in 1869. As well, she was a friend of [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] and [[Richard Wagner]], and met the French writer [[Romain Rolland]] in Rome in 1890.
Von Meysenbug was born at [[Kassel]], Hesse. Her father Carl Rivalier descended from a family of French [[Huguenots]], and received the title of Baron of Meysenbug from [[William I, Elector of Hesse|William I of Hesse-Kassel]]. The ninth of ten children, she broke with her family because of her political convictions. Two of her brothers made brilliant careers, one as a [[minister of state]] in Austria, and the other as Minister of the Karlsruhe. Von Meysenbug, however, refused to appeal to her family and lived first by joining a free community in Hamburg, and then by immigrating in 1852 to England where she lived by teaching and translating works. There, she met the republicans [[Ledru-Rollin]], [[Louis Blanc]], and [[Gottfried Kinkel]], all [[political refugee]]s; the young [[Carl Schurz]] also became acquainted with her there.
In 1862 von Meysenbug went to Italy with Olga Herzen, the daughter of [[Alexander Herzen]], known as the "father of Russian socialism" (and whose daughters she taught) and resided there. Olga Herzen married [[Gabriel Monod]] in 1873 and established herself in France, but Malwida's poor health obstructed her from joining her.
Von Meysenbug introduced Nietzsche to several of his friends, including [[Helene von Druskowitz]]. She invited [[Paul Rée]] and Nietzsche to [[Sorrento]], a town which overlooks the bay of [[Naples]], in the autumn of 1876.<ref>Human, All Too Human, Penguin Classics, p.x {{ISBN|978-0-14-044617-3}}</ref> There, Rée wrote ''The Origins of Moral Sensations'', and Nietzsche began ''[[Human, All Too Human]]''.<ref>Marion Faber, Human All Too Human, Penguin Classics, Introduction p.x</ref>
In 1901 von Meysenbug was the first woman ever to be nominated for the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] after having been nominated by the French historian [[Gabriel Monod]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.svd.se/sa-ratade-akademien-kvinnorna/av/alan-asaid|title=Så ratade Akademien kvinnorna|first=Alan|last=Asaid|publisher=}}</ref>
Malwida von Meysenbug died in Rome in 1903 and is buried in the [[Protestant Cemetery, Rome|Protestant Cemetery]] in the city.
==See also== * [[Forty-Eighters]]: She was sympathetic with the [[Revolutions of 1848 in Germany|1848 revolutions]] although not an active participant.

Co. 1907. Schurz discusses his friendship with Malwida von Meysenbug in [[s:The Reminiscences of Carl Schurz/Volume One/14 Brüning Salon — Triumph of the Reaction|Chapter 14 of Volume One]].
